<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_hex_to_bin:
```c
size_t
MHD_hex_to_bin (const char *hex,
                size_t len,
                void *bin)
{
  uint8_t *const out = (uint8_t *) bin;
  size_t r;
  size_t w;

  if (0 == len)
    return 0;
  r = 0;
  w = 0;
  if (0 != len % 2)
  {
    /* Assume the first byte is encoded with single digit */
    const int l = toxdigitvalue (hex[r++]);
    if (0 > l)
      return 0;
    out[w++] = (uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l);
  }
  while (r < len)
  {
    const int h = toxdigitvalue (hex[r++]);
    const int l = toxdigitvalue (hex[r++]);
    if ((0 > h) || (0 > l))
      return 0;
    out[w++] = (uint8_t) ( ((uint8_t) (((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) h)) << 4))
                           | ((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l)) );
  }
  mhd_assert (len == r);
  mhd_assert ((len + 1) / 2 == w);
  return w;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no places in this function that modify any of the function parameters themselves (hex, len, bin). Specific reasons:
- hex: only read via indexing (hex[r++]) and passed to toxdigitvalue; no assignment to hex or hex++. Indexing does not modify the pointer parameter or the pointed-to object (and the pointer is a pointer to const anyway), so this is compliant with the rule.
- len: only read (used in comparisons and tests), never assigned to or incremented, so the parameter is not modified.
- bin: not assigned to; it is cast to a local pointer (uint8_t *const out = (uint8_t *) bin). That initializes a local pointer from the parameter but does not modify the bin parameter itself. The writes out[w++] = ... modify the object pointed to by bin (via out), which the rule permits (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified), but do not modify the pointer parameter.
- All other assignments (r = 0; w = 0; r++, w++) are to local variables r and w, not to parameters.

Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this function.
